author: Matt

review: I love using Chromecast! It's the cheapest and easiest way to connect a 'dumb' tv to all the streaming services (with the notable exception of Amazon Instant Video).When I first started using Chromecast, it was limited to a handful of apps. Now, though, it's an open API and developers can and do bake casting into their media apps. Netflix, HBO Prime, Plex and YouTube cover most of my media needs, and now they're all available on any TV thanks to Chromecast.

author: daniel gottshall

review: Chromecast has many uses. My wife loves using it to watch Netflix because she can control it from her computer or phone (our old Panasonic "smart" tv has a clunky user interface). I like it because I can watch Youtube on tv instead of on my ancient netbook. It can also stream any tab in the Chrome browser.However, it has many downsides and shortcomings. First, it only works with Google-approves apps, such as Youtube and Netflix. If you're using some other* videostreaming website, it won't stream directly to the Chromecast. However, you can stream the entire tab, but it's a strain on the computer and router. Streaming a video in a Chrome tab also results in a certain amount of stutter and lag in the video. Third, Chromecast can only be controlled with an Android phone/tablet or the Chrome web browser. I don't normally use Chrome, and installed it just to use the Chromecast. Fourth, no physical remote is currently available. A traditional remote control can be handled purely by feel, but controlling Chromecast with a web browser or smart phone requires looking down at the "remote". And now I have yet one more app running on my computer to manage. Finally, every time my wife leaves the room, she takes the 'tv remote' (smartphone) with her.*Google has stated that Chromecast apps must meet the same standards as Google Play, which means a degree of censorship, including a ban on any adult material.
